Replies.Reply: Turner Entertainment Co All Rights Reserved.
Bollock naked with his socks still on?
Ask Jack. It's his old stamping ground.
We don't want you to go up the North, Jack.
What? And get the clap?  Clunk. The slide changes.
You work for us, Jack. We have connections in those parts.  I'd hate you to screw 'em up.  Clunk. The slide changes.
What's that? A python.  Sid laughs raucously.  Clunk. The slide changes.
What's the matter? You got gut trouble or something?
Must be a bloody contortionist  Still looking at the screen, Gerald continues.
In a thin glass.  The barman sighs petulantly, transfers the beer into a thin glass and puts it on the counter.
Why the hell aren't you here?
When can I see you? Will you be there tomorrow?
Now listen, Margaret...  The line goes dead. Carter hangs up.
I won't be using the room tonight.
You sure?  Carter gives her the money.
I'll bet this one's seen some action.
Doreen?  She seems mesmerized by what's going on.
All right, are you?  Doreen doesn 't answer.
Been staying with a friend?  Doreen nods. The undertaker coughs and thrusts another screw into the coffin.
Tell me, Doreen, did the police say anything?
What you going to do? Live with Margaret?  Doreen looks at him nervously, shakes her head and fumbles in her bag for a cigarette.
Your dad would have wanted it.  The undertaker puts the final screw in.
Is that Margaret?  Doreen nods. Frank's coffin sinks out of sight.
Doreen.  Margaret stops in her tracks and looks back at Doreen. She's still watching them.
What do you mean? You've been Frank's bird ever since her mother cleared off. You're closer to her than anyone.
I want to talk to you later.
Let her go. She'll be OK.

Replies.Didascalie: (standing, pushes the note in his top pocket)

Replies.Reply: I'm at the Las Vegas. Behind the dance hall.
Do you know a man called Albert Swift?
Replies.Didascalie: (He casts an eye around the bar.)

Replies.Reply: He was leader of our gang. He'll know what's going on in this town.
Didn't you know this is my home town?
It would be. If they were still living.
A bereavement. A death in the family.
So, who you working for these days Eric?
What are you doing? Advertising Martini?
Come off it, Eric. Who is it?
I've always ad your welfare at heart, Eric. Besides which, I'm nosy.
And you should know, if I remember rightly.
Good prospects for advancement, is there? A pension?
Do you know, I'd almost forgotten what your eyes looked like.
Replies.Didascalie: (He can't resist it any longer. He lifts the sunglasses off Eric's nose and looks into his eyes.)

Replies.Reply: They're still the same. Piss holes in the snow.
Do you know a man called Albert Swift, Eric?
Replies.Didascalie: (He moves towards the saddling ring and turns to Eric.)

Replies.Reply: Don't miss the start on my account.
Yes, I can see your problem, Mr Kinnear.
No? Funny that. Neither did I.
Right. If you can afford it.
No, do you really?  Carter turns to the table yet again.
While he was here. You went about together?
Yeah, I'll do you a favour.
I have to. Things to see to.
Told you it wouldn't take long, didn't I?  Eric opens the door and follows him out.
Oh, Cyril, eh? So it's all girls together, is it?
He's right. Tell him to save the cost of the phone call.
Was the steering faulty?  Billy shakes his head.
Old Thorpey? Haven't seen him in a long time.
Nice family, are they? Church-goers and all that?
Good. I'm off tomorrow, so I don't suppose I'll see you again.
There. Go and get your hair done.
Replies.Didascalie: (He pulls out a wad of money, and peels off some notes.)

Replies.Reply: Be good. And don't trust boys.

Replies.Didascalie: (He puts the casket on a side table.)

Replies.Reply: I fancy you. I wish I was touching you right now...
...making love to you. I want to stroke you and kiss you all over. Where are you?
The sexy, silk ones?  Anna replies. He continues softly.
When we're in South America, we'll make love in the sun. Roll over...
Save it till Sunday. I'll be back then.
What you want to tell me, Thorpey?
Replies.Didascalie: (He leaves the darkness and walks to the car.)

Replies.Reply: happens if I miss the train?
Oh, really. You're getting very optimistic in your old age, aren't you, Thorpey?
Up the stairs, Keith. The door on the right.
Why don't you go and make us all a nice cup of tea?  Carter shoves Thorpe into the room.  Keith follows.
Make us a nice cup of tea and I'll tell you. I might even let you watch.
Well now, Thorpey. It seems I've got a secret benefactor.
It's nice to know that. Isn't it, Keith?
Replies.Didascalie: (He moves into the room and opens his briefcase, which is lying on the bed.)

Replies.Reply: There's only one trouble, I don't know who to thank.
Replies.Didascalie: (He takes out a bottle of whisky.)

Replies.Reply: Now, I want to know who it is, Thorpey.
All right. If you like, Thorpey, we'll stop mucking about.  Somebody doesn't want me poking my nose into something and I happen to know what that something is.
There you are, you see. Now you could, couldn't you?
Ah, Edna, come in. Join the tea set.
Cliff Brumby. Ever been to Westsea?  Keith nods.
Ten to one, it belonged to Cliff Brumby, and like as not the bloody arcade as well. Right along the coast. Isn't that right, Thorpey?
Yes, Edna, and I must say you've been great about the ...
Keep him away from the telephone. I'm going out for a bit.
I'm an old friend of Cliff's. I want to see him.  Mrs Brumby looks at her watch irritably.
Yeah, well, tell him the Fletchers sent me.
You're a big man, but you're in bad shape. With me, it's a full-
What am I supposed to do?  I don't know where they've taken him. Do you?
And what orders would they be, Con?  Carter's hand runs over the carpet. It's going towards the chamber pot instead of the gun.
Right. Now take me back to London.
I don't want to get rough, do I?  Carter picks up the gun. He hands Edna, bis case and the casket.

Replies.Didascalie: (He points the gun at the coalshed.)

Replies.Reply: I'm going to sit in the car and whistle 'Rule, Britannia'.
Did they give you a rough time?
Does Albert Swift still live over the ferry?
All right. All right. I want to square things with you first.
I'm sorry. Here. This'll pay for a course in karate.  He throws some money on the bed. Keith tries to kick it off, but it's too painful. He clutches his testicles.
How were things between you and Frank?
But he was just another feller, wasn't he?
Why'd you see him so regular?
I don't believe you, Margaret. Frank wasn't like that.
I'm the villain in the family, remember?
You bloody whore. Frank was too careful to die like that. Who killed him?
Listen, the only reason I came back to this craphole was to find out who did it. And I won't leave until I do. You understand?
You bitch! It was you who told them I was here, wasn't it?
I'll catch up with you later, Margaret.
Of course. Where else?  The car screams off the road into a multi-storey carpark.
He must have been pretty sure I'd come.
Do me a favour. You don't really expect me to fix Kinnear on your say-so?
Just because they tried to get me on you last night, don't think you can pull the same trick. Stroll on.
Good afternoon, Mr Brumby. Carter exits.
Who's setting you up in this place?
Aren't you scared Kinnear will find out?
What does he want that bloody great country place for?
Does Brumby get a kick out of that crap?
Did Kinnear say anything? After I'd left the other night?
I want to give you an Oscar.
The young girl. Who pulled her?
Is it one of Kinnear's films?
Then he must have pulled her.
Did my brother Frank find out?
And you didn't know her last name?
And her father was my brother. And he was murdered last Sunday. Now get up and get dressed.
I know where I'll find him.
Yes, you do, Albert. Talk or I'll kill you.
Do you want to go to the toilet, Albert?
Do you want to go to the toilet, Albert?
Do you want to be dead, Albert?
Did Eric know that Frank was my brother?
I know you didn't kill him.
Are you coming in? Or do we piss about all day?
You shouldn't have shown the film to Frank.
It's Carter. Listen carefully, you hairy-faced git. I've got the film and enough evidence to put you away for a long time. All it takes is one call to the police.
I'll do a simple deal with you. All I want is ...
... but I don't want him there until six in the morning.  OK?
You couldn't win an egg and spoon race, Eric.

Stay away from the car or I'll blow you apart.  Eric darts under the jetty. Carter runs on down the steps. He can see Eric scampering along the row of cottages towards the beach. Carter starts after him.
I bet you could use a drink, could you, Eric?  He throws the bottle to Eric.
Drink up, Eric. Drink up. I want you to drink all of that. Do you understand? Drink up. Just like it was with my brother, Frank. Go on, son. Drink up.
It was you who poured it down him. Eh, Eric?  Eric takes a breather and looks pathetically at Carter. No mercy there.
Did you all have a good laugh, eh? Did you have a good laugh when he was spewing it up? The whisky is pouring all over Eric's face and suit.
Drink it! Drink it! Did you all pass the bottle round after the car went over the top?  Eric is choking.
Don't be bloody silly. You're the first since Monday.
I'll give you the key when you come down.
That was left for you this evening.  Carter walks past her into the sitting room.
Don't come that bloody flannel with me. If you're a traveller, I'm bloody Twiggy.
Inside? Why should I give house-
You keep your trap shut, Ma.
Where do you think you're going?  Carter opens the door to his room.
Suppose you tell me what the bloody hell's going on. It's my house, you know.
Stick the soft soap. Let's be having it.
You don't care a stuff, do you?
What about the lad? They took him away.
And what about you? Did you kill Brumby?
What's that gun doing in your room? Suppose I phoned the police and told them there's a bloke staying in my hotel who's planning to shoot somebody?
What, and get myself beaten up again?
Or you?  Or you? None of you knew. I knew. He was me dad.
Replies.Didascalie: (She suddenly jumps up and empties her glass in Eddie's face.)

Replies.Reply: We weren't sure where it was taking place, like.
No. Frank was a good bloke.
It's a bloody funny thing. You know a bloke for six bloody years and all the time he's as calm as gentle Jesus...
...then he goes and does a thing like that.
You don't think he might have done it on purpose?
Replies.Didascalie: (He raises his glass and drinks, then continues thoughtfully.)

Replies.Reply: Bloody good bloke. One of the best.
Don't worry. She's bound to be upset.
No. I'll be off now. I should be at work.
Frank was a good bloke. It's the least I could have done.
I couldn't believe it when I heard. Carter is suddenly attentive.
I mean, I was surprised when he didn't turn up for work.  He was always on time.
What? You mean, like, kill himself?  Eddie and Keith look at each other.
Naw. Frank? Kill himself? You what?  Carter stares at Keith, who is getting uncomfortable.
Come off it. Frank was... well...
It just would. He was always the same.
Yeah. He comes in here a bit.
Today? At the races. He always goes.
That's what he was saying about you.
Said he'd heard you were up in town. Wondered if I knew where you was staying. Wanted to look you up. Old time's sake.
You bastard. You knew they'd come back.
Replies.Didascalie: (He lowers his head to the pillow.)

Replies.Reply: Oh yes? How?  Carter takes out of his wad of money. Keith's bloodshot eyes watch him through the surrounding puff of flesh.
Frank said you were a shit and he was bloody well right.
You even screwed his wife, didn't you?  Carter shuts the door, leaving Keith shouting after him.
The poor bastard didn't even know if the kid was his.
No. No. It's not like that. I've got a husband, you know.
Killed?  I don't know anything about it.
I must go. I'm in a hurry.
Well, all right then. Twelve o'clock on the Iron Bridge.
He was all right to me.
Yes. I can't help the way I am.
He was gentlemanly. I like that.
Look, I'm me, right. You're not. We are what we are, like it or not.
He wanted me to leave Dave and marry him. Last Friday I told him it wouldn't work. Dave would have killed us both!
I had to tell Frank I couldn't see him any more. It was getting too dodgy. That was on Sunday.
He said he'd kill himself. I was frightened what you might do.
Replies.Didascalie: (She stops and looks over the bridge.)

Replies.Reply: What you doing around here then?
Thanks. So what're you doing? On your holidays?
Oh, I'm sorry to hear that.
Well, well. Small world, isn't it?
That's not always a healthy way to be...
Still got a sense of humour?
You stupid shit!  Carter walks past Ray, blowing him a kiss.
He's thinking Sid and Gerald won't like it much when they hear you've been sticking your nose in.
No shooters. Cyril said no shooters, you stupid bastard.
You're finished, Jack. You know that, don't you? I've bloody finished you.
Oh, you've still got your sense of humour?  Tell him how I've fixed him, Con.
Didn't believe us at first, did he, Con? Then Peter talked to him.
He's probably talking to her right now. Are you still going to fancy her when Gerald's finished with her face?
Carter, your car needs a wash.
Gerald Fletcher wants a word with you Cyril.
Still got your sense of humour.
You see what it's like these days, Jack.  You can't get the material.
Glenda, get Jack a drink. What is it, Jack?
Eric told me of your bereavement.
Do you know, I never knew he worked in one of my places!
If I'd known, I'd have fixed him up with something better.

Harry! Jack, I don't want to be rude, but these men have brought a lot of money with them. Glenda, you don't offer a man like Jack a drink in those piddling little glasses.  Give him the bloody bottle.
Oh... I think I'll stay as I am.
That's what you pay to find out. Right, Jack?
Harry, I don't like to push, but could you let us know how much your hand's worth?
That, Harry? That's another hundred - twenty-five pounds notes of the realm.
I'll follow that and go two hundred.
You can always see me, Harry.
That's six hundred pounds, Harry. Two hundred to follow you, and I've raised it four hundred.
Calling my bluff, are you, Harry?
Oh, come on, Harry. I haven't won, have I? Go on, you're pulling my leg.
How about that, Jack?  Old Harry thought I was having him on.
Of course, of course. Well, any time, just drop by.
I see. I think that can be arranged.
Yes, Eric. A word with you.
You know what he looks like?
Yes. I met him last year.
Oh yes. When he came up on business.
He came to see Mr Kinnear.
He was here for four days.
Could you please put my glass on the table?  Carter smiles and does just that.
To the demon king's castle, of course.
You were seen parking your car. The demon king waves his wand and I was dispatched to bring you to him. Lucky for you I waited.
Oh, he was. He told me a magic spell that would make you come.
Don't worry. He's meeting the architects at the restaurant.
He won't. He thinks I'm simple.
Especially when I play the lead.
That's why you waited for me.
Your brother? What you talking about?
The girl's name was Doreen. That's all I know.
Well, he drove it into the river.
He was drunk. Drunk as a lord.

Replies.Didascalie: (She stretches herself out sexily and smiles.)

Replies.Reply: Listen, Janet, Gerald's just got in, so I must ring off.
I'd like a word with you, Jack.
I've been asked to give you this.
Train goes at four minutes past twelve. You've just got time.
I've been asked to make sure you don't.
Are you coming, Jack? It'd be best.
He's got a new place at Burnham.
On the Durham Road. The Pantiles.
Don't let on I told you, for God's sake.
What's going on? Have you no thought for others?
Everybody knows you, Edna Garfoot. Everybody knew there'd be trouble when you moved in.
I'll send my old man to see you!
Jesus wept!  MRS BRUMBY cowers in the passenger seat.
And this is what you call having a few friends back for coffee, is it?
Running bloody riot over my bloody furniture, drinking my bloody booze...
Sandra! Unlock the door, you bitch.
What the bloody hell's all this?  Carter doesn't move.
You know what the bloody time is!
It's two o'clock in the bloody morning!
The wife says the Fletchers sent you.
What's so bloody important it couldn't wait till the morning?  Carter starts to laugh. He realizes Thorpe has lied to him.  Brumby isn't his man.
Listen, I'm not in the mood for bloody silly buggers.  Carter stands.
Listen, I don't like it when some hard nut comes pushing his way in and out my house in the middle of the night.
Bloody well tell me who sent you.
A new venture of mine. It's going to be a restaurant.
One of my lads gets a bit over-
Five grand. It belongs to you. Along with a little name I'm going to give you.
I don't know. All I know is that people were shitting bricks up at his place last Saturday. Your brother's name was mentioned. Next day, he was dead.
I don't know. That's all I was told.
I don't want them cooking in here. You can put a hatch in that wall.
Who in Christ's name is that? It's a bloody madman.  He strides away to investigate.
Jack!  Carter slams his fist hard into his gut.
I had to. It was the only way I could get at them.
I know all about Cliff's business.
I wasn't expecting you until three o'clock.
Gerald phoned us in the middle of the night, said he'd heard you've been making a nuisance of yourself.
He said it'd be doing him a big favour.
We know why you're all steamed up, and so do Gerald and Sid.
It'd be best if you got dressed first.
Put it away, Jack. You know you won't use it.
Now, Jack. Be reasonable. You know we're going to take you back - sooner or later.
See you when you've got your drawers on.
Hold it! Where do you think you're going?  Carter appears from the gate next door, covering Con with the shotgun.
Peter's very upset about his car. He's going to shit all over you.
Gerald wants to see him first.
He's told Gerald about you and Anna.
Don't let us interrupt you, Jack.
We've got to take you back to London.
But they have to be diplomatic.
If Anna could see you now.
I hope she's got understanding neighbours.
Where were you, then?  Con sees what's happened to the car and is not pleased.
Didn't even say goodbye. Just asked us to take you back - alive.
For Christ's sake, give us a fag.
I didn't know who Doreen was. Thought she was just another bird.
I dunno. He's got his ways. He knows Margaret.
No choice. I had a visit from somebody.
Cliff Brumby. He'd seen the film. He wanted to meet Doreen.

Last Sunday afternoon, Eric and two of his boys arrive with Frank and tell me that he's rumbled. Somehow, he's seen the film and was about to shoot his mouth off. They ask me for some whisky and start forcing it down his throat.
I thought they'd just duff him up a bit. Honest.
'Good.'  Albert draws deeply on his cigarette.
Yes, but listen. Christ, I didn't kill him.
They don't know how it happened.
What did Betty say... Ninety floors, I think it was.
Better to go quick like that.
